TICKETS FOR U. of M.
GAME NOW ON SALE
Tickets for the Johns Hopkins-University of Maryland
game will be sold to the undergraduates for 50 cents upon
presentation of their Athletic
Association ticket, only at the
treasurer's office in the- basement of Remsen Hall. There
will be no student tickets sold
at the stadium tomorrow.
The game will take place at
the stadium tomorrow and according to Mr. Iddins, tickets
will be sold at full price at the
gate. There will be no reserve
seats sold and all tickets admit
the holder to the rooting section.

JUNE WEEK FESTIVITIES LIBERAL ENDORSE
SOCIAL CANDIDATE
TO START NEXT FRIDAY

CONE AND YELLOTT
ELECTED TO S. C.
At a meeting of the junior
class, last Wednesday afternoon, voting for next year's
senior delegates to the Student Council was held.
Of the six nominees, Cone,
Dowell, Meeks, Parks, Towbin and Yellott; Cone and Yellott were elected.
These two men and Warlow, who was elected president
of the Student Council at the
assembly of the entire student
body, will represent the graduating class next year.

EDITORIALS
CHANGES IN CURRICULUM
S THE result of a careful investigation of the curriculum of the
College of Arts and Sciences, the Committee on Educational
Methods and Policies has outlined several important changes. The
most evident, and in the minds of many, the most important of these
revisions of the curriculum is the addition of a large number of courses.
The majority of A. B. students have felt that an insufficient number
of courses have been open to them during the last three or four years.
The University authorities, however, would seem to think that enough
courses of a rather technical or specialized nature are now open to the
students. Hence practically all the new courses are of a different
nature.
By examining the nature of these new courses one can quickly
see that the committee has done more than merely increase the number
of course. American colleges because of the great number of students
tend to become mere machines. A student takes a certain specified
number of courses. If he makes the required grades, he is given his
degree. The more brilliant students in -each class are held back by
the dull individuals. The speed is regulated by the slowest. Certain
courses are required, and, in general, the question as to whether the
student already has a sufficient knowledge of the subject is not considered. In several of the new required courses, notably English,
French, and German, the student will be given credit for the course
as soon as he is able to pass certain written tests, and will not be compelled to attend any further classes. When it is evident that the student can express himself clearly and forcibly in the English language,
he will be given full credit for the course. A reading knowledge of
French and German will be required. This change will, needless to
say, prevent many students from spending an entire year on a subject
which they already know as well as necessary.
The majority of the new courses, however, are to be presented with
the idea of enabling the student to better orient himself. The course
in mathematics, for example, will emphasize the deductive theory rather
than the solving of a large number of problems. The student will be
taught the application of calculus to science and the value of mathematics to civilization. Such a course would be far more beneficial to
the student in search of a liberal education than the present Math. 1.
At present, the student spends the vast majority of his time in this
course solving problems. He is not taught the application of these
problems to science or to general life. In a 'liberal education, a technical knowledge is not necessary. The student should be taught the
relationships of the varying subjects and in turn their relation to life
in general. He would thus better comprehend the general value of a
subject, and know where to find any specific information that he desired. The committee is certainly to be congratulated for its endeavors.

OVER-CONFIDENCE
HEN the Hopkins lacrosse team meets Maryland tomorrow
W afternoon,
it will be in a rather different position than the one
it has occupied for the last two years. The Jays will be the favorites.
Maryland has nothing to lose and everything to gain in this game.
The Maryland team is a fast and hard-fighting combination, in excellent condition. The Jay team,we believe, is the better of the two.
However, it cannot afford to falter for one minute. It faces a game
equally as hard if not harder than last week's contest. Over-confidence
has lost many games.

Rushing plans are undergoing
considerable discussion at many colleges. At the last meeting of the Interfraternity Council, of the University of Virginia, the proposal
for requiring a pledge to pass nine
hours of work before his initiation
failed to secure the necessary
unanimous vote. At the Rutgers
University two changes were made
and many proposed ones were turned down.

Purdue University approved the
constitution of the Purdue Commons Club, thereby permitting it to
be recognized as a local non-Greek
fraternity.
Their purpose is t oinculcate a
friendly, brotherly and democratic
spirit among the students of the
University; to provide an equal opportunity for all male students; to
pledge loyalty to the university; and
to provide for moral, social and intellectual culture of its members. Although it is a non-Greek fraternity,
it is not anti-Greek letter.

marking system. A student in the
chemical engineering class received
a mark of .7 out of a possible 100
points and established a new "low."
From now on, marks taken to several decimal places can be expected.

EDITORIALS
CHANGES IN CURRICULUM
S THE result of a careful investigation of the curriculum of the
College of Arts and Sciences, the Committee on Educational
Methods and Policies has outlined several important changes. The
most evident, and in the minds of many, the most important of these
revisions of the curriculum is the addition of a large number of courses.
The majority of A. B. students have felt that an insufficient number
of courses have been open to them during the last three or four years.
The University authorities, however, would seem to think that enough
courses of a rather technical or specialized nature are now open to the
students. Hence practically all the new courses are of a different
nature.
By examining the nature of these new courses one can quickly
see that the committee has done more than merely increase the number
of course. American colleges because of the great number of students
tend to become mere machines. A student takes a certain specified
number of courses. If he makes the required grades, he is given his
degree. The more brilliant students in -each class are held back by
the dull individuals. The speed is regulated by the slowest. Certain
courses are required, and, in general, the question as to whether the
student already has a sufficient knowledge of the subject is not considered. In several of the new required courses, notably English,
French, and German, the student will be given credit for the course
as soon as he is able to pass certain written tests, and will not be compelled to attend any further classes. When it is evident that the student can express himself clearly and forcibly in the English language,
he will be given full credit for the course. A reading knowledge of
French and German will be required. This change will, needless to
say, prevent many students from spending an entire year on a subject
which they already know as well as necessary.
The majority of the new courses, however, are to be presented with
the idea of enabling the student to better orient himself. The course
in mathematics, for example, will emphasize the deductive theory rather
than the solving of a large number of problems. The student will be
taught the application of calculus to science and the value of mathematics to civilization. Such a course would be far more beneficial to
the student in search of a liberal education than the present Math. 1.
At present, the student spends the vast majority of his time in this
course solving problems. He is not taught the application of these
problems to science or to general life. In a 'liberal education, a technical knowledge is not necessary. The student should be taught the
relationships of the varying subjects and in turn their relation to life
in general. He would thus better comprehend the general value of a
subject, and know where to find any specific information that he desired. The committee is certainly to be congratulated for its endeavors.

OVER-CONFIDENCE
HEN the Hopkins lacrosse team meets Maryland tomorrow
W afternoon,
it will be in a rather different position than the one
it has occupied for the last two years. The Jays will be the favorites.
Maryland has nothing to lose and everything to gain in this game.
The Maryland team is a fast and hard-fighting combination, in excellent condition. The Jay team,we believe, is the better of the two.
However, it cannot afford to falter for one minute. It faces a game
equally as hard if not harder than last week's contest. Over-confidence
has lost many games.

Rushing plans are undergoing
considerable discussion at many colleges. At the last meeting of the Interfraternity Council, of the University of Virginia, the proposal
for requiring a pledge to pass nine
hours of work before his initiation
failed to secure the necessary
unanimous vote. At the Rutgers
University two changes were made
and many proposed ones were turned down.

The faculty committee of the
Purdue University approved the
constitution of the Purdue Commons Club, thereby permitting it to
be recognized as a local non-Greek
fraternity.
Their purpose is t oinculcate a
friendly, brotherly and democratic
spirit among the students of the
University; to provide an equal opportunity for all male students; to
pledge loyalty to the university; and
to provide for moral, social and intellectual culture of its members. Although it is a non-Greek fraternity,
it is not anti-Greek letter.

Lehigh University is in the process of establishing a new accurate
marking system. A student in the
chemical engineering class received
a mark of .7 out of a possible 100
points and established a new "low."
From now on, marks taken to several decimal places can be expected.

DENTIFYING a masterpiece from an
inferior is easy when the characteristics of the master are known. The
same test can be applied to clothing.
Master clothing makers like Goodman &
Suss and Stien-Bloch have their own
peculiar characteristics in making particularly smart clothes. Naturally they
have achieved an enviable national
reputation among smart college men.
